item.latestTitle: State Veterans Home Adult Day Health Care Improvement Act of 2017

item.text:
This bill directs the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) to enter into an agreement or a contract with each state home to pay for adult day health care for a veteran eligible for, but not receiving, nursing home care.

The veteran must need such care specifically for a service-connected disability or the veteran must have a service-connected disability rated 70% or more.

Payment under each agreement or contract between the VA and a state home must equal 65% of the payment that the VA would otherwise pay to the state home if the veteran were receiving nursing home care.
item.name: Introduced in House

item.text:
This measure has not been amended since it was introduced. The summary has been expanded because action occurred on the measure.)

(Sec. 1) This bill directs the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) to enter into an agreement or a contract with each state home to pay for adult day health care for a veteran eligible for, but not receiving, nursing home care.

The veteran must need such care specifically for a service-connected disability or the veteran must have a service-connected disability rated 70% or more.

Payment under each agreement or contract between the VA and a state home must equal 65% of the payment that the VA would otherwise pay to the state home if the veteran were receiving nursing home care. Such payment constitutes full payment to the state home for such care.
item.name: Passed House without amendment

latestAction.text: Received in the Senate and Read twice and referred to the Committee on Veterans' Affairs.

item.text: Received in the Senate and Read twice and referred to the Committee on Veterans' Affairs.

DEBATE - The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 1005.
Considered under suspension of the rules. (consideration: CR H4468-4469)
Mr. Roe (TN) moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill.
Placed on the Union Calendar, Calendar No. 96.
Reported by the Committee on Veterans' Affairs. H. Rept. 115-148.

bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 163, Number 25 (Monday, February 13, 2017)]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. ZELDIN:H.R. 1005.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Article 1, Section 8 of the United States Constitution.[Page H1126]

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
